articles.headline: Senate G.O.P. Digs In to Keep Tax Cuts
articles.snippet: The Senate Republican leader, Mitch McConnell, proposed legislation to keep the tax cuts indefinitely, even for the wealthiest.
articles.abstract: The Senate Republican leader, Mitch McConnell, proposed legislation to keep the tax cuts indefinitely, even for the wealthiest.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Senate Republican leader proposed legislation on Monday to continue all of the Bush-era tax cuts indefinitely, testing the willingness of Democrats to allow a tax increase on the wealthiest Americans in a weak economy and making clear that a partisan fight will extend deep into the campaign season if not beyond.

articles.headline: G.O.P. Allies Drive Ad Spending Disparity
articles.snippet: Republican-leaning groups have been buying far more TV ads in support of their candidates than Democratic groups have.
articles.abstract: Republican-leaning groups have been buying far more TV ads in support of their candidates than Democratic groups have.
articles.lead_paragraph: Outside groups supporting Republican candidates in House and Senate races across the country have been swamping their Democratic-leaning counterparts on television since early August as the midterm election season has begun heating up.

articles.headline: Union Battle in California Threatens S.E.I.U.
articles.snippet: Workers at 331 Kaiser Permanente facilities began choosing today whether to bolt the S.E.I.U. to join a breakaway union.
articles.abstract: Workers at 331 Kaiser Permanente facilities began choosing today whether to bolt the S.E.I.U. to join a breakaway union.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif.  During his two decades building one of the largest union locals in California, Sal Rosselli earned a reputation as a cunning strategist and street fighter  someone who often vilified hospital chains during contract battles.

articles.headline: Medical Industry Ties Often Undisclosed in Journals
articles.snippet: Researchers found that consultants to orthopedic device companies often failed to divulge the payments in articles.
articles.abstract: Researchers found that consultants to orthopedic device companies often failed to divulge the payments in articles.
articles.lead_paragraph: Twenty-five out of 32 highly paid consultants to medical device companies in 2007, or their publishers, failed to reveal the financial connections in journal articles the following year, according to a study released on Monday.

articles.headline: For the Bad News Bulls, Adversity Is Opportunity
articles.snippet: At a time when hedge funds seem gripped by fear, a few big-name investors are betting on large companies that are increasing their sales in China, Brazil and India.
articles.abstract: At a time when hedge funds seem gripped by fear, a few big-name investors are betting on large companies that are increasing their sales in China, Brazil and India.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  For the better part of a year, a small band of investors and economists has been arguing that the torrent of grim news on jobs and the stagnating United States economy is shrouding an immutable fact: the recovery is at hand  you just can’t see it yet.

articles.headline: Lionsgate and Televisa Unite on Films
articles.snippet: Pantelion Films will focus on Hispanic American viewers by releasing eight to 10 movies annually over five years.
articles.abstract: Pantelion Films will focus on Hispanic American viewers by releasing eight to 10 movies annually over five years.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Lionsgate’s African-American-focused film business, anchored by Tyler Perry titles, has become a gold mine for the studio. Movies with predominantly black casts that tell stories rooted in black culture — surprise! — bring out a sizable black audience.

articles.headline: A Walk Along Stone’s Wall Street
articles.snippet: Oliver Stone’s sequel to “Wall Street” is not likely to be embraced by the finance industry, as the original was.
articles.abstract: Oliver Stone’s sequel to “Wall Street” is not likely to be embraced by the finance industry, as the original was.
articles.lead_paragraph: “You know, half the people in this place could be prosecuted.”

articles.headline: Consumer Candidate May Avoid a Vote
articles.snippet: The Obama administration is reportedly considering appointing the legal scholar Elizabeth Warren to run a new consumer bureau on a temporary basis to avoid a confirmation battle.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration is reportedly considering appointing the legal scholar Elizabeth Warren to run a new consumer bureau on a temporary basis to avoid a confirmation battle.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is considering appointing the legal scholar Elizabeth Warren to run a new consumer bureau on a temporary basis to avoid a potentially bruising confirmation battle in the Senate, according to people who have been briefed on the search.

articles.headline: 3-D Printing Spurs a Manufacturing Revolution
articles.snippet: New technology is giving rise to never-before-possible businesses that are selling products like iPhone cases, doorknobs, perfume bottles and architectural models.
articles.abstract: New technology is giving rise to never-before-possible businesses that are selling products like iPhone cases, doorknobs, perfume bottles and architectural models.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Businesses in the South Park district of San Francisco generally sell either Web technology or sandwiches and burritos. Bespoke Innovations plans to sell designer body parts.

articles.headline: Cuba’s Public-Sector Layoffs Signal Major Shift
articles.snippet: The government plans to lay off more than half a million people, expecting they will move into private businesses.
articles.abstract: The government plans to lay off more than half a million people, expecting they will move into private businesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY  In perhaps the clearest sign yet that economic change is gathering pace in Cuba, the government plans to lay off more than half a million people from the public sector in the expectation that they will move into private businesses, Cuba’s labor federation said Monday.

articles.headline: Young Greeks Seek Options Elsewhere
articles.snippet: A growing number of young college graduates are leaving Greece as the recession strangles a job market already crippled by a culture of cronyism.
articles.abstract: A growing number of young college graduates are leaving Greece as the recession strangles a job market already crippled by a culture of cronyism.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — In two weeks, Alexandra Mallosi, 29, will be packing her bags and leaving the quiet Athens suburb of Holargos for Abu Dhabi to start a job as a hotel sales manager.
